## 1. Choose the Right Cut – Less Fat = Less Flare‑Ups

| Cut (beef / pork) | Typical intramuscular fat (marbling) | Why it matters |
|-------------------|--------------------------------------|----------------|
| **Sirloin, tenderloin, eye‑of‑round, top‑round, flank steak** | 2–5 % | Lean meat heats more evenly, so you reach the desired doneness without needing very high temperatures that cause charring. |
| **Ribeye, T‑bone, pork belly, spareribs** | 12–30 % | Fat drips onto the grill or pan, causing flare‑ups and smoke → more PAHs.  If you love these cuts, use a **low‑and‑slow** method (e.g., oven‑braise) rather than direct high‑heat grilling. |

**Tip:** Trim any visible external fat before cooking; it reduces smoke and the amount of PAHs that can deposit on the meat surface.
